content: dwarves out on the sea go discourage our enemy we will purge the world more
conquering the dragon sure hi there I shall craft a simple ship using things
you can find at home dwarfs don't like the sea so they hate
these dragons to start off the simple build I traced
out the bottom of the ship first then I cut out the cardboard piece yeah that's
a good shape for a boat next up we have the owed packages I will try to make
planks from card stock let's see if it works
I just cut out strips of varying width then glued them on the lower deck as
planks I also made sure to leave gaps between
the planks it looks better I then cut away the excess and carve in
some wood textures I didn't cut instead I worked with the side of the blade
this results in wider and deeper textures
having a flat floor in a ship like this is a bit strange so I bent the entire
piece like this problem solved do this before gluing on the planks as I should
have done it time to make the sides of the ship from card stock as well that
should do and I made two then I attached the pieces with hot glue by the way I
put the templates and measurements of this build on drive through RPG with the
PDF you should be able to craft the ship effortlessly using the card stock from
which I cut out the sides we can easily get a fitting piece that goes along the
edge great that fits well I glued it on and cut out more planks of the same
shape to save time here you could make peasant level plank work by just using
straight strips however the curved ones might be worth
it for the looks here I have one side done just slapping on the pieces works
best the overlap is cut away later I will also cut away these bits from the
ends to improve the shape of the ship when gluing on the planks make sure to
use shorter bits as well okay all of the planks are in place I cut away the
overlap and removed these bits then I made the woodgrain textures on the
entire boat there we go I figured out it is also a good idea to put some planks
on the inside just a long curved strip like the one I glued on the outside when
working with thin cardstock strips keep in mind that the measurement don't have
to be exact as the pieces can easily be bent and forced to fit well I won't make
more details yet as I just made a poll on patreon my patrons get to decide the
theme of this ship elven dwarven or viking for now I will work on the mast
I began by cutting a bit of barbecue stick this seems to be of suitable
thickness just as it is because real good that is not good enough for us
I'm exaggerated wood textures by going wild
with the blade actually I now knew that this is going
to be a dwarf ship I made another mast and these sticks that will hold the
sails the masts and sails will be inspired by the Byzantine Roman I'll
just make it a bit more dwarfee I just noticed the mast need to be a bit
shorter here are the final pieces all correct
measurements can be found in the templates next I attached the mast
matches are good for this step as they are square in shape with a few textured
match bits I was able to glue in the mast as shown here
I made sure to remove most of the excess
glue as too much glue hides the textures the mast stayed in place surprisingly
well as long as I place them straight up I let the front mast lean a bit forward
because I saw it in a picture while the glue dried I decided to make the sails
from paper this is slightly thicker than the usual office paper yeah that should
be a good start this detail makes no sense but it looks more dwarven I
roughed this up to make the sales less uneven the back edges of the sails will
get some detail I cut these fitting strips of cardboard and glued them on
both sides of each sale some more detail for the sails I decided to make
something that resembles a Thor's hammer symbol I cut out four symbols from card
stock and then painted them black in this way you won't mess up the sail once
they were painted I glued the symbols on the sails
you
while at it I also painted these strips black really carefully should have
painted these before gluing them in I'll attach the sails once everything is
painted so back to the ship for now due to the sails I cut away some from the
front here to make this ship more suitable for dwarves I decided to add
metal plating on the front ah it broke but it doesn't matter I'll fix it with
another piece here we have all the ready pieces
I used a similar design as I did with the Dwarven stronghold that one is for
the stern the rear end of the bolt gluing was easier when I bent the pieces
first you know what would have been even easier using hot glue there we go I also
cut away the excess from this piece and glued in something to cover this part
this will be a good dwarf ship if you are enjoying the content make sure to
subscribe and like this video in the end that helps YouTube in its confusion to
show this video to other interested viewers those are shields I made ten
different shields by first cutting out a shape and then gluing on some details
that's all of the shields imagine each shield belonging into a unique dwarven
warrior who is ready to fight and die for his skin I also made a flag from the
same paper as the sails with tiny hammers I then glued the flag onto a
textured toothpick it's quite nice to make these small details all you need is
a bit of patience here we have two great pikes polearms good for slaying dragons
made from just toothpicks a bit of junk plastic glued in between and some thread
around the shaft if you want to see more custom miniature weapons I made a
beautiful grade sphere in the video where I built this guy go check it out
if you haven't already anyway I will start painting the parts of the ship
starting with black first I painted the ship then the shields and also the pie
cuts using a black acrylic bail now I'll paint the ship first mixing a
golden ish brown this is the way I often paint wood I learned the basics for this
method from that magic craft actually this channel wouldn't exist if it wasn't
for him now when you are so inspiring that you accidentally create competition
for your own channel well I then painted some selected areas with a yellow orange
color especially on the edges after working with the orange I dry brushed
with a tan yeah that reveals more texture I did go a bit too heavy so I
covered some spot with a dark wash afterwards
next i drybrushed all steel parts with gunmetal starting off with the plating
here using plenty of paint so perhaps this is more of a over brush on this
side you can see that I use too much paint then I moved over to the shields
I'll cover everything with the gunmetal first the copper or gold paint comes
later this is impressive for being just cardstock they are even quite hard from
the base coat next I painted the pipes I think copper works better than the
gold paint for now I painted the details on the shields
then the end blades on the boats
using the same paint I also painted the details on the sails and the flag just a
thin layer of copper on the black base coat next I grabbed my pressure strong
tone wash and applied it on most parts starting with the Pyke's then come the
mast and the Boone this really works wonder on the roughed up wooden sticks I
apologize for my calluses but I do wear them with pride yeah
these sticks are now looking real good apply more wash if you want even more
contrast I think I washed these two times I also used the wash over the
metallic part darkening and increasing the contrast of the shields and metal
platings on the ship as you can see I apply the
wash quite generously
okay I then did some edge highlighting with white and made some dots that look
like rivets on the metal I worked the rest of the pieces in a similar way I
was not completely sure what I was doing so don't take too much mini painting
advice from me and Here I am also doing some edge highlights on the planks
back to the Pyke's I dry brush the wound around thread with gold yeah that was
the missing part of these weapons now they looked quite nice I did the same
for the smaller bits on the shields I was not happy with them before now I am
I thought about the sails for a while and figured out just black or gold is a
better choice of colour for the details I chose gold and painted here you can
see the difference between the copper and gold details blue goes well with
gold so I painted some of the shield edges with this color I'll attach the
sails with a golden rope just painting it with my fingers and perhaps I'll
figure out some other uses for this thread time for some soothing practice
barely managing this but yeah I got it I just soothed the sail into place if you
do this be careful you don't want the paper to break at the last loop
once you have the sale in place just secure the thread with a knot and some
blue a good alternative to this method would be using small loops made from
steel wire preferably colored with gold if the
thread is tight enough the first sale should be easily attached like this then
the short thread is glued under a portside shield good that works I
attached the front sail to the mast like this when doing tiny knot work remember
to apply a bit of glue to secure the knots now I just glued the rest of the
shield's on to the sides
the dwarves have their flag on the stern side and the Pyke's can be moved around
freely be brave now Iran we sail to the dragon
Shore where they spawn men say it has no Wharf but nothing stops at Wharf these
scaly beasts burned our homeland now we will conquer and wear the scales asana
